case_name: Union of India v. Exen Industries

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1612 of 1972 was filed.

facts.text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment Order dated 16th November 1971 of the Delhi High Court in C.W. No. 25-D of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment Order dated the 16th November, 1971 of the Delhi High Court in C.W. No. 25-D of 1966.

facts.text: Vora and Mehta formed a partnership under the name of Exen Industries and manufactured fountain pens.

anchor.surface_text: Alagiriswami, J.-formed a partnership under the name of Exen Industries and were manufacturing fountain pens. In December 1963 the partnership was

facts.text: In December 1963 the partnership was dissolved.

anchor.surface_text: In December 1963 the partnership was dissolved and Vora took in another partner and companytinued the industry under the original name of Exen

facts.text: Vora took in another partner and continued the industry under the original name of Exen Industries.

anchor.surface_text: and Vora took in another partner and companytinued the industry under the original name of Exen Industries. Mehta started another business also of manufacturing fountain pens

facts.text: Mehta started another business of manufacturing fountain pens under the name of Premier Products.

facts.text: Under the deed of dissolution of partnership all the machineries and other assets were equally divided between the two partners.

anchor.surface_text: Under the deed of dissolution of partnership all the machineries and other assets were equally divided between the two partners and Vora was also given the benefit

facts.text: The respondent firm's new Exen Industries applied for import licences for necessary raw materials and were granted 50 per cent of what the original Exen Industries were getting.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the respondent firms new Exen Industries applied for import licences for necessary raw materials and were granted 50 per cent of what the original Exen

facts.text: The respondent firm filed a writ petition C.W. No. 25-D of 1966 out of which this appeal arises.

anchor.surface_text: Industries were getting. Thereupon the respondent firm filed a writ petition out of which this appeal arises.

facts.text: A Division Bench of the Delhi High Court allowed the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the Delhi High Court allowed the writ petition and quashed the order of the Government dated 3rd  December, 1965

facts.text: Delhi High Court quashed the order of the Government dated 3rd December 1965.

anchor.surface_text: and quashed the order of the Government dated 3rd  December, 1965 and directed the appellants, who were respondents in the writ petition.

facts.text: Delhi High Court directed the appellants to consider the claim of the respondent on the basis of its own production and not on the basis that the production of M/s. Exen Industries was divided between the petitioner and Shri Mehta in December 1963.

anchor.surface_text: to companysider the claim of the respondent  who will hereafter be called the petitioner  on the basis of its own production and number on the basis that the production of M s. Exen Industries was divided between the petitioner and Shri Mehta in  December 1963.

facts.text: Petitioner's actual production was the same as before the dissolution as the installed capacity of the factory was double that of actual capacity and production.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners case was that his actual production was the same as before the dissolution as the installed capacity of the factory was double that of actual capacity

facts.text: In the division of the machinery and assets of the partnership the half given to the petitioner was for his level of production and only the other half consisting of the spare and the unutilised capacity of the machinery and stock were given to Mehta.

anchor.surface_text: and production, that in the division of the machinery and assets of the partnership the half given to the petitioner was for his level of production and only the other half companysisting of the spare and the unutilised capacity of the machinery and stock were given to Mehta

facts.text: The High Court thought that the respondents before it thought that by the division of the machinery and stock of the old firm, half of the productive capacity fell to the share of each partner at the dissolution.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court thought that the respondents before it fell into a subtle error inasmuch as they thought that by the division of the machinery and stock of the old firm, half of the productive capacity fell to the share of each partner at the dissolution,

facts.text: The partnership dissolution deed provided that the machinery, raw materials and finished goods in stock as also other assets and liabilities were to be divided equally between the two partners.

anchor.surface_text: The partnership dissolution deed do clearly provided that the machinery, raw materials and finished goods in stock as also other assets and liabilities were to be divided equally between the two partners.

facts.text: Vora got the advantage to continue the same old name and the benefit of the existing import licences as well as the pending applications for import licences.

anchor.surface_text: The only advantage which Vora got was to companytinue the same old name and the benefit of the existing import licences as well as the pending applications for import licences.

facts.text: The deed did not provide that Vora was to get the benefit of the old import entitlement for all future times nor the benefit of all the production of the dissolved firm for future import licences.

anchor.surface_text: It ,did number provide that he was to get the benefit of the old import entitlement for all future times number was it provided that he was to get the benefit of all the production of the dissolved firm for the purpose of future import licences.

facts.text: The Government divided the old import entitlement equally between the two partners.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances the most equitable way of dealing with the matter was to divide the old import entitlement equally between the two partners, which is what the Government did.

anchor.surface_text: Exen Industries was borne on the registers of the Directorate General of Technical Development and the quota of import licence granted  1  1966 1 S.C.R. 242. 36 9 to the new Exen Industries is on the basis of the Directorates recommendation.

concepts.interpretation: Petitioner cannot succeed on contention affecting Mehta's interest without joining him as party

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: the basis of certified requirements for twelve months companysumption. But the very same paragraph shows that the certified requirements will haveto b

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners contention was based on paragraph 73 of the Hind book of Rules Procedure in relation to import trade control. That paragraph as far as is relevant reads as follows Basis of Licensing.- 1  The applicants are advised to submit applications for their requirements duly certified by the certifying authority concerned. The licences for raw materials will ordinarily be issued subject to the availability of foreign exchange on the basis of certified requirements for twelve months consumption, but the certified requirements will be scrutinised by the licensing authority and an appropriate reduction will where necessary be made after taking into accounts the stock held on the date of application and the expected arrivals against licences in hand the quantum of import likely to be available through the commercial channels the quantum of similar goods or substitutes likely to be available from indigenous sources and the past imports of the item in question by the applicant.

concepts.interpretation: Certified requirements scrutinised considering past production and imports of predecessor firm; successor firm's entitlement linked to past history of dissolved partnership

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: n actual user and before the importation of the goods against the said licence there is a division of the factory amongst the partners of the business

concepts.unlisted_label: Paragraph 73, Handbook of Rules & Procedure relating to Import Trade Control
concepts.unlisted_description: Basis of Licensing for import licences

anchor.surface_text: paragraph 88 2  c  Division of business- i  Where an import licence has been granted to an actual user and before the importation of the goods against the said licence there is a division of the factory amongst the partners of the business and the name of the business factory as appearing in the licence is retained by one of the succeeding parties or number of them is allowed to use such name. the succeeding parties, number being the licence holders, cannot operate upon the said licence. In such cases also, joint application by all the succeeding parties should be made to the licensing authority concerned for reissue of separate licences in their favour, in lieu of the original licence, in proportion to the portion of the factory taken over by each succeeding party supported by documentary evidence showing the division of the business factory and particulars of the established importer quotas, if any, possessed by the succeeding parties.

concepts.interpretation: On division of partnership/factory, licences to be reissued proportionately to each succeeding party; principle applies to future licences

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ace after the importation of the goods against the said licence, the imported goods become part of

concepts.unlisted_label: Paragraph 88(2)(c), Handbook of Rules & Procedure relating to Import Trade Control
concepts.unlisted_description: Division of business/import licences on partnership dissolution or factory division

anchor.surface_text: According to paragraph 71 of the Hand-Book in the case of industries borne on the registers of the Directorate General of Technical Development, licences will normally be issued on the basis of, the recommendation of the Directorate General of Technical Development.

concepts.interpretation: Licences issued on recommendation of Directorate for registered industries like Exen Industries

concepts.unlisted_description: Basis for licensing industries registered with Directorate General of Technical Development

issues.text: Whether the new Exen Industries is the same as the old Exen Industries and entitled to the full import entitlement of the old partnership based on its post-dissolution production?

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand it appears to us that it is the High Court that has fallen into a subtle error of thinking that the petitioner is the same as the old Exen Industries. When the machinery of a factory is divided into two equal halves it is number possible to accept the companytention that one of the partners to the partnership got the actual production capacity and the other partner got the unutilised spare capacity.

issues.text: Whether under paragraph 73 of the Handbook of Rules Procedure in relation to import trade control, the licensing authority can issue import licences to the petitioner solely on certified requirements without scrutinising past production and imports of the dissolved predecessor partnership?

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners contention was based on paragraph 73 of the Hind book of Rules Procedure in relation to import trade companytrol. That paragraph as far as is relevant reads as follows Basis of Licensing.- 1  The applicants are advised to submit applications for their requirements duly certified by the certifying authority companycerned. The licences for raw materials will ordinarily be issued subject to the availability of foreign exchange on the basis of certified requirements for twelve months companysumption, but the certified requirements will be scrutinised by the licensing authority and an appropriate reduction will where necessary be made after taking into accounts the stock held on the date of application and the expected arrivals against licences in hand the quantum of import likely to be available through the companymercial channels the quantum of similar goods or substitutes likely to be available from indigenous sources and the past imports of the item in question by the applicant.

issues.text: Whether the petitioner can succeed on a contention that affects Mehta's interest in import entitlements without joining Mehta as a party to the proceedings?

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the petitioner cannot be allowed to put forward such a contention without making Mehta a party to these proceedings and no decision against the interest of Mehta could be made in his absence.

issues.text: Whether the principle underlying paragraph 88(2)(c) of the Handbook requiring proportionate division of import licences upon division of business or partnership dissolution applies also to entitlements for future import licences?

anchor.surface_text: paragraph 88 2  c  Division of business- i  Where an import licence has been granted to an actual user and before the importation of the goods against the said licence there is a division of the factory amongst the partners of the business and the name of the business factory as appearing in the licence is retained by one of the succeeding parties or number of them is allowed to use such name. the succeeding parties, number being the licence holders, cannot operate upon the said licence. In such cases also, joint application by all the succeeding parties should be made to the licensing authority concerned for reissue of separate licences in their favour, in lieu of the original licence, in proportion to the portion of the factory taken over by each succeeding party supported by documentary evidence showing the division of the business factory and particulars of the established importer quotas, if any, possessed by the succeeding parties.

issues.text: Whether import licences for industries like Exen Industries registered with the Directorate General of Technical Development should be issued on the basis of the recommendation of that Directorate as per paragraph 71 of the Handbook?

anchor.surface_text: According to paragraph 71 of the Hand-Book in the case of industries borne on the registers of the Directorate General of Technical Development, licences will numbermally be issued on the basis of, the recommendation of the Directorate General of Technical Development.

arguments.claim: Petitioner entitled to import licences on same basis as before dissolution because actual production remained same, installed capacity was double actual production, and machinery divided such that petitioner got capacity for his production level while Mehta got only spare/unutilised capacity

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners case was that his actual production was the same as before the dissolution as the installed capacity of the factory was double that of actual capacity and production, that in the division of the machinery and assets of the partnership the half given to the petitioner was for his level of production and only the other half companysisting of the spare and the unutilised capacity of the machinery and stock were given to Mehta and he was, therefore, entitled to get import licences after the dissolution as before it.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: rtner at the dissolution, and that the Government failed to observe the distinction between installed capacity and actual capacity. On the other hand

arguments.court_reasoning: Machinery divided equally into two halves; impossible for one partner to get actual production capacity and other only spare capacity when divided equally; plain error

arguments.claim: Government erred in assuming equal division of productive capacity from machinery/stock division and failed to distinguish installed capacity from actual capacity

anchor.surface_text: The High Court thought that the respondents before it fell into a subtle error inasmuch as they thought that by the division of the machinery and stock of the old firm, half of the productive capacity fell to the share of each partner at the dissolution, and that the Government failed to observe the distinction between installed capacity and actual capacity.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: o equal halves it is number possible to accept the companytention that one of the partners to the partnership got the actual production capacity and t

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court itself erred in thinking new firm same as old; equal machinery division precludes one getting actual and other spare capacity

arguments.claim: New Exen Industries not same as old partnership; equal machinery division means each partner gets equal productive capacity, not one actual and one spare

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand it appears to us that it is the High Court that has fallen into a subtle error of thinking that the petitioner is the same as the old Exen Industries. When the machinery of a factory is divided into two equal halves it is number possible to accept the companytention that one of the partners to the partnership got the actual production capacity and the other partner got the unutilised spare capacity.

arguments.claim: Import licences granted on basis of actual production, not installed capacity

anchor.surface_text: The import licences are given on the basis of actual production. In such a case where the machinery is divided equally between the two partners, merely because one partner goes into production immediately and because of the excess installed capacity is enabled to produce the same quantity as the partnership firm produced before the dissolution it cannot be said that he has got the actual production capacity

arguments.claim: Partnership deed provided only for equal division of machinery/assets and gave Vora benefit of existing/pending licences but not old import entitlement or production for future licences

anchor.surface_text: The partnership dissolution deed do clearly provided that the machinery, raw materials and finished goods in stock as also other assets and liabilities were to be divided equally between the two partners. The only advantage which Vora got was to companytinue the same old name and the benefit of the existing import licences as well as the pending applications for import licences. It ,did number provide that he was to get the benefit of the old import entitlement for all future times number was it provided that he was to get the benefit of all the production of the dissolved firm for the purpose of future import licences.

arguments.claim: Most equitable approach is to divide old import entitlement equally between partners on dissolution, as Government did

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances the most equitable way of dealing with the matter was to divide the old import entitlement equally between the two partners, which is what the Government did.

arguments.claim: Accepting petitioner's installed capacity argument would lead to both partners entitled to full old entitlement (double total), impossible due to limited foreign exchange and raw materials

anchor.surface_text: If the petitioners companytention that because the installed capacity even from half the machinery which he got was equal to the old productive capacity is accepted it follows logically that it should apply to the other partner also. ... That means that between them both they would be entitled for import licences at twice the value of what the partnership was originally getting. Nei- ther is foreign exchange available in plenty number the supply of raw materials so great that import licences for raw materials companyld be given without reference to companysiderations of availability of these two.

arguments.court_reasoning: Certified requirements to be scrutinised including past imports/production of applicant (predecessor firm); entitlement not divorced from past history of dissolved partnership

arguments.claim: Petitioner cannot argue for full entitlement affecting Mehta's share without joining Mehta as party

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the petitioner cannot be allowed to put forward such a companytention without making Mehta a party to these proceedings and numberdecision against the interest of Mehta companyld be made in his absence.

arguments.claim: Principle in para 88(2)(c) requiring proportionate reissue of existing licences on partnership division applies by analogy to future import entitlements

anchor.surface_text: Another reason why we companysider that the petitioner cannot get anything more than what he was given would be apparent from a reading of paragraph 88 2  c  and understanding the principle underlying it. ... If that is so in respect of the importation of goods against current licences, same principle should apply for future licences also.

arguments.claim: Principle of equal division of import entitlements on partnership dissolution recognised in Controller v. Amichand

anchor.surface_text: The principle that when a partnership is dissolved the import- licences would have to be equally divided among the partners has been implicitly recognised by this Court in its decision in Controller V. Amichand 1 .

arguments.claim: For registered industries like Exen, licences issued on recommendation of Directorate General of Technical Development per para 71; done here

anchor.surface_text: According to paragraph 71 of the Hand-Book in the case of industries borne on the registers of the Directorate General of Technical Development, licences will numbermally be issued on the basis of, the recommendation of the Directorate General of Technical Development. Exen Industries was borne on the registers of the Directorate General of Technical Development and the quota of import licence granted  1  1966 1 S.C.R. 242. 36 9 to the new Exen Industries is on the basis of the Directorates recommendation.

holdings.text: The High Court fell into a subtle error of thinking that the petitioner is the same as the old Exen Industries. When the machinery of a factory is divided into two equal halves it is not possible to accept the contention that one of the partners got the actual production capacity and the other got the unutilised spare capacity.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand it appears to us that it is the High Court that has fallen into a subtle error of thinking that the petitioner is the same as the old Exen Industries. When the machinery of a factory is divided into two equal halves it is number possible to accept the companytention that one of the partners to the partnership got the actual production capacity and the other partner got the unutilised spare capacity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Equal division of machinery per dissolution deed implies equal productive capacity for each partner; rejects distinction between actual and spare capacity.

holdings.text: The import licences are given on the basis of actual production.

anchor.surface_text: The import licences are given on the basis of actual production.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Licensing policy ties entitlements to actual output, not installed capacity, especially post equal asset division.

holdings.text: The partnership dissolution deed did not provide that Vora was to get the benefit of the old import entitlement for all future times nor the benefit of all the production of the dissolved firm for future import licences.

anchor.surface_text: It ,did number provide that he was to get the benefit of the old import entitlement for all future times number was it provided that he was to get the benefit of all the production of the dissolved firm for the purpose of future import licences.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of dissolution deed limits benefits to existing/pending licences, not future entitlements.

holdings.text: The most equitable way of dealing with the matter was to divide the old import entitlement equally between the two partners, which is what the Government did.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances the most equitable way of dealing with the matter was to divide the old import entitlement equally between the two partners, which is what the Government did.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Balances interests post-dissolution; avoids over-entitlement given limited resources.

holdings.text: Certified requirements under paragraph 73 will be scrutinised including past imports and actual production of the predecessor firm; petitioner's entitlement cannot be considered divorced from its past history as partner in dissolved partnership.

anchor.surface_text: But the very same paragraph shows that the certified requirements will haveto be scrutinised after taking into account the past imports of the item in question by the applicant and the actual production during the past licensing period and the estimated production for the period in question. Now in this case there were numberpast imports of the item in question by the applicant but only by the former Exen Industries

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies para 73 scrutiny factors to successor firm linked to predecessor's history.

holdings.text: The petitioner cannot be allowed to put forward such a contention without making Mehta a party to these proceedings and no decision against the interest of Mehta could be made in his absence.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the petitioner cannot be allowed to put forward such a contention without making Mehta a party to these proceedings and no decision against the interest of Mehta could be made in his absence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Natural justice requires hearing affected party before deciding against their interest.

holdings.text: If that is so in respect of the importation of goods against current licences, same principle should apply for future licences also.

anchor.surface_text: If that is so in respect of the importation of goods against current licences, same principle should apply for future licences also.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Extends para 88(2)(c) proportionate division principle by analogy to future entitlements.

holdings.text: The principle that when a partnership is dissolved the import-licences would have to be equally divided among the partners has been implicitly recognised by this Court in its decision in Controller v. Amichand.

anchor.surface_text: The principle that when a partnership is dissolved the import- licences would have to be equally divided among the partners has been implicitly recognised by this Court in its decision in Controller V. Amichand 1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows implicit precedent supporting equal division.

holdings.text: In the case of industries borne on the registers of the Directorate General of Technical Development, licences will normally be issued on the basis of the recommendation of the Directorate General of Technical Development; Exen Industries quota granted on that basis.

anchor.surface_text: According to paragraph 71 of the Hand-Book in the case of industries borne on the registers of the Directorate General of Technical Development, licences will numbermally be issued on the basis of, the recommendation of the Directorate General of Technical Development. Exen Industries was borne on the registers of the Directorate General of Technical Development and the quota of import licence granted

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of para 71 to registered industry.

holdings.text: The petitioner was not entitled to anything more than what was granted to him by the Government and the High Court was in error in assuming that the actual capacity was retained fully by the petitioner and only the spare capacity was given to Mehta.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, satisfied that the petitioner was number entitled to anything more than what was granted to him by the Government and the High Court was in error in assuming that the actual capacity was retained full  by the petitioner and only the spare capacity was given to Mehta.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Synthesis of above: upholds Government's 50% allocation; reverses High Court.

edges.explanation: Holding corrects the view that new firm is same as old and entitled to full entitlement

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand it appears to us that it is the High Court that has fallen into a subtle error of thinking that the petitioner is the same as the old Exen Industries. When the machinery of a factory is divided into two equal halves it is number possible to accept the companytention that one of the partners to the partnership got the actual production capacity and the other partner got the unutilised spare capacity.

We are, therefore, satisfied that the petitioner was number entitled to anything more than what was granted to him by the Government and the High Court was in error in assuming that the actual capacity was retained full by the petitioner and only the spare capacity was given to Mehta.
